Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2011 09:27AM - edited Oct 5, 2011 09:28AM by Wendyspet For me, the taste got better the farther away from chemo--and then bam, it started again.  I switched to sports drinks during chemo, mostly because I was getting headaches and dizzy and needed the electrolytes.  That helped 100%.  I watered down anything I was drinking, and when the crappy mouth bothered me I took a swig.  Plain water tasted slimy, and I had been a water junkie! My stomach was hungry, but my mouth wanted to spit it out!  so weird.  I could taste lemon flavor (costco has these little lemon bites), and salt.  Other than that--nothing.  So I ate alot of salty noodles.  I fluctuated 5-7 pounds over my usual weight, and still have some. The taste bothered me more than losing my hair.
Posts.Title: Horrible Taste Lingering! Carla9112 NannaBaby

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 01:29PM Wendyspet wrote: Claire-I went through the same thing.  My biopsy came back benign, but the radiologist was not convinced so I had a lumpectomy.  Unfortunately, and I don't want to scare you, but mine was malignant.  I was told by my doctors to just 'get it out'.  And you are doing the right thing.  It is scarey, and life-changing, but you need to know what it is. I also looked at my BS and said "what did I do?" -- I am healthy, under weight, and don't smoke and drink very little.  She said it is very much a menopausal disease.  You can't beat yourself up over this--it just happens and no one is exempt no matter how healthy they are. Hugs and good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Still not diagnosed, but surgeon wants a lumpectomy claireinaz claireinaz

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 08:39AM Wendyspet wrote: Would you happen to know how much of their donations go towards research?  I saw on Komen's website that for them it was only around 25%, (but that wasn't their most current financial statement).
Posts.Title: Consider National Breast Cancer Coalition instead of Komen mkkjd60 nancyh

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 06:04PM - edited Aug 8, 2011 06:05PM by Wendyspet Hi Beanpole I went to the best in town also.  I had to wait 6 weeks for a lumpectomy, and then after the malignant diagnosis, I would have waited another 6 weeks for mastectomies.  I bailed and went to another surgeon who got me in for my BMX in 10 days.  You need to do what you are comfortable with, but if you need to have additional surgery, you might have more waiting with this surgeon.  I really liked the first surgeon and the office staff, but I absolutely could not wait anymore...  It might be worth a call to the surgeon to see what you might expect in terms of future surgeries, if necessary (and I hope they arent!)

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2011 04:46AM - edited Aug 13, 2011 04:47AM by Wendyspet As I remember, the radiologist charged $1200, of which my insurance discounted to around $700.  I had to pay it out of pocket too because of a $4000 deductible.  I am in AZ.  You could call the radiologist office and see how much it is.  I am sure they could tell you. Oh, I had a core needle biopsy.
Posts.Title: Biopsy cost? vanlex vanlex

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 09:40AM Wendyspet wrote: TLC had a mastectomy camisole I got for about $45.  The one at TLC had velcro pockets to hold the drains.  Also got a prescription from my doc and went to a store at a local hospital and got another.  I thought I needed one to wear and one to wash--was I wrong.  For the first couple days I was wrapped with an ace bandage.  I only wore the camisole for a couple days after that, and then the drains came out. I had BMX on June 12.  It wasn't as bad as I thought it would be.  Eat alot of protein, as your body is healing.  Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Where to get Mastectomy Products blubecca7 DocBabs

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 11:18AM Wendyspet wrote: Bev - my sis had melanoma in 2010. I was diagnosed bc in 2011.  Although everyone has their own theories on cancer, I am thinking it is some kind of genetics that hasn't been discovered yet. You and your sister can be a great support system for each other at this time. I'm sorry,  no one wants to have cancer, but to be able to have a sister to compare notes, vent, discuss options, call anytime.  I'm jealous.  I know that sounds stupid.  I had a friend with bc two years prior to mine, and she called me after every one of my chemo treatments.  It was so nice to talk to someone who had been thru it, and make sure I wasn't crazy or abnormal. This site is great, but conversation is better! I had bmx, and didn't find it bad at all.  I only needed pain meds for about 2 days after.  The hospital and doctors should take care of your pain.  Wishing you and your sister speedy recovery.
Posts.Title: Sister and I just diagnosed within a week of each other bevg49 AnewBeginning

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2012 01:43AM Wendyspet wrote: You sound very calm and level-headed, and certainly more knowledgeable than I was going into this.  I just want to encourage you to have the lump removed, even if they tell you its benign--because that's exactly what happened to me.  My radiologist was convinced that it was malignant and did not believe she got a good sample when my results came back benign.  I owe her a thank you card. It might be time to take care of YOU for awhile.
Posts.Title: Upcoming biopsy dreniger marlenet

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2011 04:26PM Wendyspet wrote: Van--my path numbers are the same as yours.  I decided to do the BMX mostly because I didn't want to live on the 6 month 'waiting' for mammo results plan, and I did not want to do radiation.  All of my doctors said the recurrance rates were the same with lumpectomy + rads vs. mastectomy.  But for some reason I thought radiation would be a pain. Yes, I do miss my nipples, but my tumor was very close to one so that one would have been gone anyways.  And I did have multi-focal areas of DCIS in the cancerous breast, (found with the BMX path)--so I would have been repeating the lumpectomies many times over.  I have been really lucky/blessed throughout out this: chemo wasn't bad (just finished); and since I already had implants, they just swapped them out for new ones during the BMX.  I still have to have my nipples done. I think that Sarah and I may be in the minority.  I get the impression that there are more women who choose lumpectomies over BMX.  I have to admit I started second-guessing my decision before my surgery.  All my doctors questioned me, but left the decision up to me.  Sarah brings up a good point though--age should make a difference.  It probably would be preferable to keep your breasts if you are younger like she was.  But I am 47.  Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: How do you know if Mastectomy is right for me? vanlex the7gerbers

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2011 01:40PM Wendyspet wrote: Beetlebum--my onc said the same thing when I asked him about running the blood tests for cancer markers (I don't know the exact term).  He said if your markers go up, it could cause you stress that doesn't mean anything, because the markers aren't reliable, and because survival rates don't change regardless of knowing early that the disease has progressed. I am stage 1 and only had a head ct done because I was having headaches.

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2011 04:32PM Wendyspet wrote: I got mine cut short before it started leaving, maybe 3" bangs and layered in back.  It is now really thin on top, but I still have some on the sides.  I am just going to keep vacuuming my pillow and seeing how it goes.  I am halfway through TCH, but I don't see anything new sprouting on the top at all!  Maybe I'm giving it a head start?? (wishful thinking, ha ha) I thought it was really was bad to have handfuls of hair come out during washing and combing, but I got used to it.  Vacuuming my pillow and the bathroom is now part of the morning routine, but I'm saving so much time just putting on a wig!

I don't think any of this stuff is helping, but I've invested too much money to stop now.  If you hair grew fast before chemo, you might not have a problem.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 02:55PM Wendyspet wrote: Gracie - I went topless to work 4 months pfc.  We met friends for dinner on Sunday, me without my wig, and she encouraged me to ditch the wig at work.  When I look back at my pics, I had very little hair. I wore the wig til Thursday of that week, announced I would be topless on Friday, and had my hair dyed with an organic color Thursday night.  Since it was January, if my neck got cold, I wore a scarf, and I bought a cute gray beanie cap with a flower on it!  You have any of those cute light-weight scaves?   Point being, we are bothered more than others by it. If you think you are ready, then you are!  There's always gonna be some well-meaner who says the totally wrong thing. I showed up bald at halloween as Charlie Brown and got alot of attention.  Some people were pretty freaked out about my baldness and were giving me their phone numbers and lots of hugs, but by that time I was a month pfc--over it!  But it was totally worth it to get my chubby hubby in a Snoopy costume...

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 03:26PM - edited Oct 28, 2011 03:27PM by Wendyspet Lesley, I probably would have an attorney look at this, but you might not want to pursue it because it takes forever and it takes energy.  So when you are all done with treatment, you might still be re-living it all because the legal process is slooow.  But at least maybe a complaint with your local medical board--If they missed your diagnosis, who knows how many others have slipped through the cracks. My IDC was close to the nipple and the bs said I might lose it anyway.  I figured I wanted them to match (and I wasn't up for the watch-and-wait process), so I had both done.  I didn't find the recovery very painful at all.  I was back to work 12 days after my double MX, but if I had anything other than a desk job, I would have stayed home longer. Best of luck on all your tests.  Don't plan much for yourself--all the doctor's visits/tests/hurry-up-and-wait sure is tiring.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2011 09:46AM Wendyspet wrote: I thought I lost mine late too, but I had TCH every 3 weeks.  I think I was into my second treatment when it started leaving.  BUT... there was a lady who had TC x 4 who finished right when I started, and she said her hair thinned, but her hair looked perfectly normal to me.  She didn't loose it all!  But when I was complaining to genetics nurse about losing my hair, she said "well at least you know the chemo is doing what it's supposed to do."  I would worry a little about my dosage if I didn't loose my hair.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 01:45PM Wendyspet wrote: As has been said, I wanted to look back on this and said I did everything I could to make the cancer go away.  I did not have any positive nodes, but am her2neu positive and chemo is standard.  I considered this my 'insurance'.  I just had my third out of six treatment, and am still working.  Yes, funny things happen, some days you just don't feel 100%, but I have only a couple days, like this weekend, where I will hit the bed and hibernate.  My onc. gives me plenty of meds and is very receptive to my concerns/symptoms.  You really are more scared of the side effects than anything else.  Best of luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Chemo vs. No Chemo edoyrest B123

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 04:05PM Wendyspet wrote: Boy I hate to tell you this, because someone told me the same thing when I started this journey and I was not happy...but, my core biopsy came back benign but by lumpectomy came back malignant.  Just get it out is what all my doctors said to me.  (After the biopsy, my radiologist send me a letter saying she was not convinced she was in the right area and recommended I get it removed.) But 80% are benign, just keep that in mind.  I hope you don't go down my path, but finding out for sure is better than leaving it in!  There aren't many words right now that can ease the fright, I know. But you are doing the right thing being proactive with your health.  Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Abnormal Mammogram vs Benign Core Needle Biopsy MindyM dlb823

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 05:05PM Wendyspet wrote: The lumpectomy came back Grade 3, her 2 positive.  After living thru all that uncertainty and sleepless nights, I decided I didn't want to do that again...so I opted for mastectomies.  I started second guessing my decision, then my BS said I might lose my right nipple anyways because she had to get more margins, as my lump was too close to the nipple.  Those factors made me opt for double mastectomies--let's make them the same while we are in there.  I know its not for everyone, but my gyn, onc and bs let me make the decision. So the mastectomy results from my right breast came back with multifocal DCIS that weren't showing on the mammogram. So I would have been back again!  So I made the right decision for me, but since I am her 2 positive, I had to have chemo.  I guess they haven't tested herceptin by itself, and it is usually given with 6 courses of chemo.  I just had #5 and it certainly wasn't as bad as I had imagined.   My idea was to go aggressive.  I didn't want to look back and have regrets.  The mastectomy wasn't bad--I went back to work after 12 days.  The chemo hasn't been horrible--I've missed 2 days of work so far (besides treatment days).  But, you have to be comfortable with whatever surgery you do.  I already had implants and was used to the feeling, so they just inserted new ones at my mastectomies.  I consider myself lucky in that regard.  I do miss my nipples though! There are lots and lots of threads about lumpectomy vs. mastectomy.  But I hope you don't have to make that decision.
Posts.Title: Abnormal Mammogram vs Benign Core Needle Biopsy MindyM dlb823

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2012 04:03PM Wendyspet wrote: Keeping busy is good, also don't spend much time googling up on what could happen--it will be more scarey than do good. My first BS (the 'best around') set me about 6 weeks out for my lumpectomy (which was really an easy surgery for me--I thought the needle biopsy was worse).  When she wanted to set me about 7 weeks out for mastectomies, I knew I couldn't wait, I was sleepless, losing weight, and stressed out.  I found another surgeon who did it in 12 days!    Some ladies here are fine with waiting.  Not me.  The point is, just know you have options.  I have to say the first few days of any "plan" are the worst--you can't get it out of your head.  Then, you will put it on the back burner and get on living your life.  Maybe ask your BS for an anti-anxiety medicine on the 9th--just so you have it on hand in case you are staring at the ceiling at 3 a.m.  I also found it much easier to sleep with the television or radio on, because when it was quiet, my brain ran wild!  80% are benign, and I hope you are one of those!
Posts.Title: Awaiting Excisional Biopsy LoriBeth blg

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2011 02:39AM - edited Oct 31, 2011 02:41AM by Wendyspet Yes you are at the hardest part right now.  The stress can be terrible.  Have they discussed removing the lump altogether--rather than guessing whether they are in the "right" place?  I think I would insist.  I don't want to scare you unnecessarily, but some biopsies come back with the wrong diagnosis. Remember, 80% are benign.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: The worst part is not knowing... lc1975 awb

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 02:41PM Wendyspet wrote: Have you looked into your state coverage?  My state has a coverage, but you have to be under a certain income level to qualify.  The problem here is that they won't really tell you what that level is, I guess because they don't want anyone under-earning on purpose. I also thought that the new Obama care deleted pre-existing conditions--but maybe someone more knowledgeable will chime in.    My last thought is that since October is "pink" month, my imaging place offered a discount for cash--if you are able to wait that long.  Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Should I be even more worried? skylar321 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 12:01PM Wendyspet wrote: Here's what I would do if it is bothering you that much.  Get the doctor's phone number and stand there until she calls and makes an appointment.  And then go with her to the appointment.  Or maybe get other family members involved in your crusade. Here's why--I told my sister "that mole on your back doesn't look right."  She shrugged.  She then walked around for months with an unexplained pain under her arm--then had her future DIL feel the "hard spot" under her arm.  It was still a month after that before she went to a doctor and started having appropriate testing.  She died 4 months later of melanoma.  Hindsight is 20-20 and I kick myself every day because I wasn't more agressive with her.   Possibly the end result would have been the same anyway.  But if nothing else, she did it "her way."  If you truly are persistent with your mother, and being a real nag, then you did everything you could and you CAN'T feel guilty about that.
Posts.Title: Frustrated with my Mom. Any advice? Kimmer1975 kristysvn

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 08:59PM Wendyspet wrote: Yuelin:  My surgeon told me that after mastectomies, I would be done with treatments.  Well that was simply wrong.  If your tumor is her2 neu positive, you probably will have chemo.  (I have 6 treatments of chemo with herceptin, and then herceptin every three weeks for a full year.)  The her2neu test takes a few days longer to come in, so it is possible that you don't have your results yet.  I did not have problems with the mastectomies, and am not having many problems with chemo so far, but this week is only #3 so its hard to say.  But there was one week, before I started treatment, when I had a doctor's appointment every single day!  That was a tiring week.  Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Job and treatment timeframe yuelin ANA_424

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2011 05:02AM Wendyspet wrote: I hope everything went well for you.  You might want to consider having the suspicious lump(s) removed either way--just to make sure.  The waiting part is truly the hardest.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: I feel like a yo-yo Sichernde Sichernde

Posts.Content: Wendyspet wrote: I was diagnosed 4/15 after a lumpectomy with 1.1 cm IDC, also removed a .8 DCIS.  Grade 3, ER,PR and HER2 positive.  I have decided on mastectomies, and need to have lymph nodes biopsied too, I haven't had that done yet.  This surgery is not scheduled until the middle of June!  I like my surgeon.  She is supposed to be the best in the area, and this is an important surgery--but that doesn't seem to help me get through the sleepless nights. Oh, part of the concern is that my sister passed about a year ago from melanoma.   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Should I find a new surgeon? Wendyspet timekpr

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 02:30AM Wendyspet wrote: I had a clip and an immediate mammo. Some thoughts: I would call your gyn and get another referral, as well as a copy of your report.  Maybe the gyn will be willing to discuss this delay issue with you?  You need to be comfortable with your surgeon going forward.  I changed surgeons.  This is someone you could be seeing for years and you need to be comfortable with this person.  What will happen next time?
Posts.Title: Biopsy follow-up questions maiyen Fergy

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 09:16PM Wendyspet wrote: I used the latisse for my lashes during chemo and didnt have a problem applying it.  I got a little eyeliner brush from the drugstore.  I don't think it stopped my lashes from falling out--at one time during chemo I think I only had 2 bottom lashes on one side.  I also would brush it on one of my brows that was thin--but I don't think it made a difference there. But once my lashes started growing again, they are sooo much better than they ever were!  Lots of them.  I love latisse.  We can buy it from the spas.  It ranges from $75 - $100, and I am now using it every other night just to save some $.

Posts.Title: Husbands in the procedure rooms? vanlex minkarejn

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 06:01PM Wendyspet wrote: marti-I am in the exact same boat.  The radiologist who did my core biopsy told my gyn that she may not have hit the right spot because she was sure it wasn't "normal" breast tissue.  So I too see a surgeon on the 17th.  By the time they schedule surgery and you get the reports back, it could be another month before you know!  This is the first time I have read anything about "wires" though, so I am going to definitely ask about that.  This forum is a great place to learn. Hang in there!  I am with you in spirit.  Keep updating.
Posts.Title: inconclusive path report, now for lumpectomy marticcrn mdoak

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2011 01:11PM Wendyspet wrote: Dear Vanlex: I had a biopsy which came back negative, and then got a letter from my radiologist that she wasn't convinced of the findings.  My Gyn told me "just get it out".  I had the lump removed about 6 weeks later and it was cancerous.  I know I am the exception, and I don't want to scare you, but I am glad I got it out instead of just letting it sit.  I really don't know why the biopsy came back negative, it looked to everyone that the radiologist was in the right spot. Please also remember that 80% of lumps are benign.  Most of the people you will meet here are in the 20%, so keep that in mind.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: core biopsy or surgery? vanlex SoCalLisa

Posts.Title: Any tips for heartburn CoolBreeze LindaVA

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 02:52PM Wendyspet wrote: FOR SURE!  If you can't rest until you know what it is--then do it.  Call your first doctor and ask for another referral.  Maybe he can send you to a radiologist or lab that will just do it and not give you grief.  Go get an answer.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow JackieD JackieD

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 12:55PM Wendyspet wrote: I was diagnosed 4/15/11.  BMX 5/12.  I was her2 positive and have had 5 of my 6 chemos.  I am not having radiation because of the BMX's and no positive nodes.  My (hopefully) last chemo is September 21 and then a year of Herceptin and 5 years of tamoxifin.  I finally now feel, right now, that I can/will get past this.  It does take awhile.  For awhile there is nothing but fear and doctor's appointments.  Once treatment starts, you mentally start feeling better, like you are doing something and moving forward.  But chemos can make you feel emotional/angry/sad too, like menopause. Have your sister ask for anxiety/sleep/depression medicine.  Maybe she might not want to take it, but its nice knowing that its in the house if needed. Also, during recovery and chemo I very much appreciated my family & friends bringing over food--even though I didn't ask for it.  It was nice to have leftovers in the fridge to munch on.  The steroids made me hungry almost all the time. You sound like a good sister.  I hope she is talking to you about her feelings.  (sometimes husbands just don't get it--they want to "fix" everything.)  I would give almost anything to have my sister with me now, but she passed from melanoma in 2010.  She wouldn't talk about her fears at the time, she very much tried to run away from it all.  But I can't beat myself up for that--that's just the way she was.  Good luck to both you and your sister.
Posts.Title: When does life go back to normal? GetSparky dontworrybehappy

Posts.Content: Wendyspet wrote: My liver enzymes were high the past 2 weeks.  from 30 to the 90s, but my MO said wouldn't think about cutting back my TCH dose until they get to the 115s.  So I am back to blood tests every week.  I had TCH #4 today. He quizzed me on how many Tylenols and pain pills I had been taking, and whether or not I had been drinking alcohol.  No alcohol, and the only tylenol was 2 weeks ago.  He said it is common for chemo to affect the liver. Anyone else?  Something I can do?  Otherwise, I have found chemo not to be too bad at all. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Liver enzymes high. Wendyspet Beeb75

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2011 01:13PM Wendyspet wrote: Mine started dropping right before my second chemo, June 30, and it has been coming out in gobs mostly in the shower.  I am vacuuming every day too.  Although I have lost alot, I still have hair.  I got it cut pretty short right before chemo though.  I was going to buzz it but my husband suggested I just leave it for now.  But it continues to leave every day at about the same rate. A friend of mine said if you shave it, don't shave it too short, because it will feel like you are sleeping on a porcupine.
